ratings.question_text: I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: What is the name of your TA?
comments: Steve Liapas
Stephen Liapis
Steve
Stephen Liapis
Stephen Liapis
Stephen LIapis
Steve Liapis

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: The lecture time could have been used much more wisely. Knowing that we were ultimately accountable for knowing the tree species was the main factor driving our learning. The slide-driven lectures did little in the way of preparing us for what we ultimately needed to know. There needed to be more synthesis of material rather than a litany of species in each lecture. Field trips and practicing ID were the most useful.
the fieldtrips were the most useful for learning dendrology.
Field trips, fun and useful.
The field trips and hands-on approach to tree identification.
The field trips were phenomenally helpful.

The fieldtrips were fun and helpful. Prof. Camp is very charming and nurturing. Getting the dean to deliver an engaging guest lecture was a booking success. I appreciated that Prof. Camp forced us to learn order-level taxonomy; it makes the plant evolutionary narrative all the richer.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: powerpoint slides need to be revised. focus more on cladistics and systematics rather than going through each order and family. focus less on tropical plants, more on regional or at least national ecosystems.

Make the slide presentations more natural. More time should be spent on reviewing the natural/evolutionary history of groups and how they are related rather than going through a list of example species and their features. I know a few scattered facts about phylogenetics now, but no comprehensive understanding.
Sometimes there was a lack of communication of expectations between the instructor and students, as well as between the instructor and her TA.
I think more time looking at specimens and understanding how the families and orders are different would have been helpful.

There is significant room for improvement:1. Most taxonomy/systematics classes teach a systematic method for field identification that is based on the dichotomous keys used in the most prominent local flora guide. Both in lecture and in the field, students were given characters haphazardly. It is clear that the professor knows the species, but a more systematic explanation of the deductions used to arrive at the species identification would be appreciated.2. The midterm field practicum tested material that was not heavily emphasized in lecture (e.g. bark and twig characters) and some material that had yet to even be covered. I appreciate some of the logistical constraints (i.e. deciduousness), but the midterm left many students frustrated.3. Fresh specimens (and herbarium specimens) were provided in class once. I find that spending hands-on time with fresh specimens in class and taking as much time as is needed to really memorize the distinguishing traits is byfar the best way for me to become proficient in their identification.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: very helpful in providing review sessions and open office hours.

The TA was generous with his time, leading extra tree ID walks and review sessions. The communication between the instructor and TA needed to be improved. The class sometimes did not receive important information
Both made themselves very available to students.
They were both extremely helpful and were always available.
The TA did what was required of him and he is very knowledgable about the subject matter.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: not the most important class, most useful before leaves dropped because we were actually out in the field.

I am happy this coures is offered. It would be embarrassing to graduate from the oldest school of forestry in the country and not know at least the basic northeastern forest species. The course also helps to synthesize other classes like Stand Dynamics and Silviculture by providing familiarity with the autecology of the major New England forest species that are so often referenced.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: interested in learning native flora.
To learn trees
It is an essential starting point for any forestry student.
I wanted to develop a solid understanding of the trees of southern New England.

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: yes, i learned the plants, but the course could have been only a half semester and fewer credits.
Not entirely. I learned a great number of tree species, but not much more.
Yes, although I would have liked to focus more on the real world work and less on the historical/natural history aspect.
Definitely, thought it was great and I learned a lot.
Absolutely.
Minor elements of disappointment. But I do feel that I have gained some level of proficiency in field identification of the key New England forest species.

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: yes.
Yes, and the information from this course exceeded expectations.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Find a group of students that want to learn tree ID and do an informal training or maybe even an independent study. Books, discussion and tree walks are enough for a motivated group.
If you put the time into studying your species well before tests, it will be especially helpful for you.
Spend as much time as possible looking at trees on the streets of New Haven and in the parks.

You will learn the key New England forest species. You will become proficient in their field identification. You will probably enjoy the friendliness and easy-going disposition of Prof. Camp. You will probably not enjoy the midterm field practicum as it takes place when only half of the species you are responsible for have been covered in lecture.
